Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution as a homosexual in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Refugee Protection Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Alleged formal complaint, incidents of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence regarding formal complaint, isolated incidents not amounting to persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned credibility of applicant's evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution, state protection, internal flight alternative
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for factual findings, reasonableness for mixed questions of fact and law
Decision_Rationale: Incidents were isolated and not persecution, state protection presumed available, internal flight alternative existed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Well-founded fear of persecution and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear questioned due to delayed reporting and omission of abuse details
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee protection
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to family violence and inadequate investigation into mother's death
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider expert evidence and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Expert testimony on normalization of abuse
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear and lack of state protection under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Past persecution and failure to report abuse

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of subjective fear and state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear dismissed despite minor status and trauma
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions for minors and refugee claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Sexual abuse and lack of state protection in Jamaica
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Minor status and failure to address key evidence
Crimes.Application_Error: Ignored expert evidence and minor-specific considerations
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Expert testimony on victim behavior in abuse cases
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear and lack of state protection
Crimes.Application_Factor: Age of applicant and psychological impact of abuse

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Threats to kill if reported, prolonged abuse
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, expert evidence on incest normalization
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unfairly dismissed due to delayed reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 97(1) – well-founded fear of persecution

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supported by behavioral norms in abuse victims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Improperly challenged due to delayed disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA – refugee protection based on persecution

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Long duration, familial power imbalance, lack of intervention
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, expert evidence on normalized abuse behavior
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unfairly doubted due to non-reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA – Convention refugee definition

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: IRPA sections on inadmissibility and smuggling
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to consider minor status and trauma
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Abuse in country of origin justifying flight
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Claimant testimony, teacher report, expert opinion
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Lack of procedural fairness and credibility misassessment
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to address expert evidence and minor-specific vulnerabilities

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Failure to report abuse due to fear and systemic neglect
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse by parent, no protective response from authorities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Direct testimony, teacher report, expert evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and consistent with behavioral patterns
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unfairly dismissed due to lack of formal complaint
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA – refugee protection based on state inability to protect

Legal_Issue: Bias, reasonableness, credibility assessment, discrimination vs. persecution, state protection
Legal_Provision: Section 97 and 98 of IRPA, Section 3(1)(b) of the Charter
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution based on Roma ethnicity in Hungary
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, availability of state protection, distinction between discrimination and persecution
Application_Error: Alleged bias and unfair treatment by IRB
Assessment_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of bias, standard of reasonableness
Evidence_Ignored: Allegations of bias lacked sufficient context to support claim
Application_Factor: Credibility, membership in particular social group, risk upon return
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed, no basis to overturn IRB decision

Credibility_Assessment: Omissions and inconsistencies in testimony noted, not patently unreasonable
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution due to authored report in Bolivia
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of claimant, Availability of state protection in Bolivia
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision upheld

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Legal_Provision: Section 97 (protection from torture, risk to life, etc.)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds
Incidents not rising to level of persecution
LTTE extortion tied to general country conditions
Application_Error: Alleged error in assessing persecution and future risk
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision upheld
Claim dismissed

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution in Pakistan; Board found documents likely fraudulent with inconsistencies and contradictions; issues deemed local, not national
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claim for protection, not residency status
Misrepresentation_Element: Yes – documentation likely forged, common practice in Pakistan
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Used: Inconsistent testimony, questionable documentation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony, lack of credible evidence supporting national-level persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Negative – applicant's credibility undermined by inconsistencies and potential forgery
Decision_Outcome: Internal flight alternative (IFA) found available; refugee claim denied
Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee, protection from removal
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious possibility of persecution on balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: Persecution risk was local, not nationwide; applicant failed to prove no safe internal flight alternative
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Threats and intimidation after reporting sexual assault
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Unknown individuals linked to the reported sexual assault
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Targeted due to cooperation with authorities in reporting crime
Crimes.Threat_Source: Non-state actors possibly connected to religious figure
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible; some inconsistencies noted but explanations provided
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Flawed by Board; concerns over implausibility and lack of corroboration deemed unreasonable

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of power and trust by religious authority
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High individualized risk due to perpetrator's position and threats
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Continuing threat from perpetrator and associates
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible; corroborated by mental health professional
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unjustifiably dismissed by Board; patent unreasonableness found

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Protection from Sexual Assault
Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: State failure to protect victim of sexual assault
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Religious leader (priest) and state authorities (by omission)
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Lack of effective state response to serious gender-based violence
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High due to absence of state protection
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic inability or unwillingness to protect victims
Crimes.Threat_Source: Non-state actor with state complicity or neglect
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board's assessment flawed; ignored corroborating evidence

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Persecution through sexual assault by religious leader
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Abuse of spiritual authority, ongoing threats, fear of retaliation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High individualized risk of continued persecution
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Sustained abuse and intimidation based on vulnerability
Crimes.Threat_Source: Religious figure in position of power
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board's rejection deemed patently unreasonable

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Retaliation and intimidation for reporting sexual assault
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Unknown actors possibly linked to perpetrator or institution
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Chilling effect on access to justice
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of further obstruction and retaliation
Crimes.Risk_Type: Impunity and systemic barriers to justice
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Fear of reporting crimes due to threats
Crimes.Threat_Source: Non-state actors retaliating against cooperation with justice
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Reasonable and consistent despite minor discrepancies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to properly assess credibility; findings unreasonable

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1(F)(a) of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by Mexican police for refusing corruption
Legal_Framework: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Targeted_Group: Civilians subjected to systematic abuse by police
State_Protection_Assessment: Internal flight alternative considered available in Monterrey
Risk_Factor: Association with a repressive state apparatus
Credibility: Credible evidence of complicity based on conduct and awards
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate due to availability of internal flight alternative
Victim_Basis: Civilians subject to torture and false imprisonment

Sub_Crime_Type: False imprisonment as part of crimes against humanity
Aggravating_Factors: High confession rates linked to coercion
Criminality_Severity: High – part of systematic attacks on civilians
Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk due to institutional tolerance
Targeted_Individual: Detainees used to achieve high conviction rates
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to disengage despite knowledge

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Article 1(F)(a) of the Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by Mexican police for refusing corruption
Legal_Framework: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Risk_Factor: Active participation in or tolerance of torture
Credibility: Credible evidence of complicity based on role and recognition
State_Protection_Adequacy: Deemed adequate due to internal flight possibility

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that the Applicant had a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Kiev
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no question certified
Credibility_Assessment: The Applicant's claims of anti-Semitic persecution were not fully credible; issues found to be localized and personal in nature
Evidence_Type: Evidence regarding localized threats, state protection in Kiev, resource limitations affecting all citizens, personal vendetta by Shevchuk
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Kiev
Legal_Standard: Risk of persecution must exist in every part of the home country
Application_Factor: Personalized threat, lack of systemic anti-Semitism, availability of state protection in Kiev
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed due to viable IFA in Kiev

Application_Facts: Applicant faced persecution by state agents (OJI) in Costa Rica; seeking help from these agents would have increased danger; lawyer attempted to involve Ombudsman without success
Procedural_Issue: RPD's determination that applicant did not adequately seek state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence of persecution by state agents, attempt to engage Ombudsman
Decision_Outcome: RPD’s conclusion found unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee based on lack of state protection
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of state protection can be rebutted with clear and convincing evidence of state's inability to protect
Decision_Rationale: Seeking protection from persecuting state agents would have increased risk; efforts through Ombudsman failed; RPD's finding was unreasonable under the circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Application_Facts: Khan was 57 days short of the 1,095-day physical presence requirement; maintained family ties and economic contributions in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum 1,095 days of physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge's decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence, family ties, economic contributions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient documented physical presence days
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court found the Citizenship Judge's strict interpretation unreasonable
Outcome: Appeal allowed; case remitted for reconsideration
Remedy_Sought: Reevaluation of residency under a contextual approach
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residence in Canada over four years under s 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Residency should be assessed contextually, considering factors beyond strict physical presence, especially in exceptional circumstances

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in the CLA, which engaged in subversive acts; minimal involvement and lack of knowledge acknowledged but deemed irrelevant
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review analyzed Board's discretion, jurisprudence application, and adequacy of reasons
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Immigration and Refugee Board jurisdiction under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of CLA membership, evidence of CLA’s subversive activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility not challenged on admission of membership
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Broad interpretation of 'membership' under subsection 34(1)(f); knowledge or active involvement not required

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion against a government by force
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with armed subversive group
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Organization (CLA) engaged in armed attacks against Namibia's government
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership in organization using force to subvert government
Crimes.Organization_Involved: CLA (Congress of Leaders of Angola or similar liberation/armed group)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant admitted membership, though claimed nominal involvement
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Relevance of lack of knowledge or minimal involvement under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Direct admission, organizational records or reports on CLA activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanation of nominal involvement considered but legally insufficient
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Consistency of admission, lack of denial
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 34(1)(f) of IRPA
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility leading to refusal of refugee status and potential deportation

Application_Facts: Shing Timothy Wong's application for Canadian citizenship was approved despite concerns about his residency duration.
Residency_Compliance: Unclear due to inconsistent record and insufficient reasoning
Procedural_Issue: Sparse reasons provided by citizenship judge; failure to specify residency test or explain evidence weighing
Evidence_Used: Record of residency duration, application materials
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in the record; lack of clarity on how evidence was assessed
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside
Outcome: Appeal allowed; matter remitted to a different citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and detailed reasons required under subsection 14(2)
Decision_Rationale: The original decision lacked sufficient reasoning to allow for meaningful review, necessitating remittal for proper assessment

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act and Regulations - Retired Persons Category Eligibility
Application_Facts: Applicant applied under the 'retired persons' category but did not meet age requirements before the category was revoked
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with eligibility criteria for retired persons category
Procedural_Issue: Refusal to grant an interview; decision made on paper review without exceptional circumstances
Evidence_Used: Application documents, statutory criteria, policy guidelines
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence demonstrating exceptional circumstances warranting an interview
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer's decision upheld
Outcome: Application dismissed, costs awarded to respondents
Relief_Sought: Judicial review via writ of certiorari and mandamus
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of Immigration Act and Regulations
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer acted within legal authority; no mandatory duty to interview; no exceptional circumstances shown

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence and residency centralization requirements
Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act - 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present for 567 days and absent for 893 days; Citizenship Judge relied on ties to Canada without sufficient assessment of centralization of mode of living
Residency_Compliance: No - failed to meet 1095-day requirement and insufficient evidence of centralizing life in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to properly apply legal test for residency; decision found unreasonable
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, ties to Canada (e.g., family, employment, property)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of whether respondent centralized mode of living in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Original approval of citizenship application set aside
Relief_Sought: Review and correction of erroneous citizenship approval
Remedy_Sought: Remand for reconsideration by a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Residency under the Citizenship Act: physical presence or centralization of mode of living
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge's conclusion was not supported by adequate reasoning or proper legal analysis regarding centralization of residence

Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 3(c), 16, 24, 71, 75, and 91 of Samson Election Law
Application_Facts: The applicant was disqualified for not meeting residency requirements after complaints were filed. The law does not explicitly outline a pre-election disqualification process, but Section 16 implies broad authority for the Electoral Supervisor.
Procedural_Issue: Lack of explicit pre-election disqualification process in the law
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether the Electoral Supervisor exceeded jurisdiction by disqualifying the applicant after the nomination meeting
Decision_Outcome: Electoral Supervisor did not exceed jurisdiction; application for judicial review dismissed
Outcome: Applicant's name remained off the candidate list
Decision_Rationale: Section 16 implies broad authority for the Electoral Supervisor over elections

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear not objectively well-founded; insufficient evidence to prove lack of state protection or internal flight alternative
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 96, IRPA (refugee definition)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Persecution fears from a gang and a municipal employee in Venezuela
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection and internal flight alternative
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified as ignored; rather, evidence was deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable possibility standard, not balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to prove lack of state protection or impossibility of internal relocation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to report threats to police
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 97, IRPA (persons in need of protection)
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Extortion by gang and harassment by municipal employee
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Denial of refugee status by IRB
Crimes.Credibility: Partially undermined due to lack of reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections 96–97

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to provide sufficient evidence to rebut state protection presumption
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a), IRPA (burden of proof on claimant)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Anonymous police complaint without identifying details
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of Federal Court over IRB decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detail and verification in anonymous complaint
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to inconsistencies
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee or protected person
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question or overturning of decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and convincing evidence to rebut state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Anonymous complaint insufficient to prove lack of state protection

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repetition of demands, abuse of public office
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No physical harm reported, limited geographic threat
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high, depending on enforcement context
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Personalized based on prior employment dispute
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially compromised by lack of corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies and lack of reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA sections related to refugee determination

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee status criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicants fled Sierra Leone due to civil war and sought refugee status in Canada; visa officer determined their experiences were part of generalized conflict, not targeted persecution; conflict had ended and conditions improved in Sierra Leone
Claimant_Status: Foreign national seeking refugee status abroad
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – applicants were outside Canada seeking entry
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging visa officer’s refusal of refugee application
Evidence_Used: Evidence of improved conditions in Sierra Leone, end of civil conflict
Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found applicants did not demonstrate targeted persecution or lack of durable solution
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer's refusal of refugee status upheld
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; applicants remain ineligible for refugee status
Relief_Sought: Grant of refugee status and admission to Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Criteria for Convention refugee abroad or humanitarian-protected person class under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The applicants' experiences were part of a generalized conflict rather than targeted persecution; country conditions in Sierra Leone had improved, allowing for safe repatriation

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada on a temporary visa and remained beyond the authorized period before applying for refugee protection.
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of IRB decisions
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony regarding fear of spousal abuse
Documentary evidence on country conditions in Jamaica
Record of visa entry and expiry dates
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider key evidence supporting subjective fear and state protection gaps
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found lack of subjective and objective fear; court found assessment patently unreasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination by a new panel of the IRB
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Article 1A(2) of the Refugee Convention
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter for state protection analysis
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board inadequately analyzed applicant’s fear and Jamaica’s capacity to protect victims of domestic violence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 114(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: After refugee claim was denied, applicant remained in Canada despite being subject to a removal order.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant under removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging basis of original refugee determination affecting removal liability
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court authority to review IRB decisions impacting enforceability of removal orders
Evidence_Used: Testimony about threats from ex-partner
Country condition reports on domestic violence in Jamaica
IRB decision record and removal order documentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board overlooked credible evidence of risk and misinterpreted state protection availability
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned applicant’s credibility; court found this assessment unreasonable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee protection denied, removal order issued
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case referred back for re-determination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal and refugee status recognition
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-hearing before a different IRB panel
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of persecution or cruel and unusual treatment due to domestic violence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient analysis of Jamaica’s ability to protect women facing domestic abuse; errors in evidence interpretation
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to family targeting and political activity
Procedural_Issue: Fresh evidence post-decision was deemed inadmissible
Evidence_Used: Credibility assessment by IRB
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting persecution claims
Credibility_Assessment: IRB found the applicant not credible
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, IRB’s decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of IRB's negative credibility finding
Decision_Rationale: IRB's decision was reasonable and supported by evidence

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: RPD failed to conduct proper state protection analysis, did not reference legal test or presumption of state protection
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate state protection analysis, lack of transparent reasoning
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of transparent reasoning connecting evidence to conclusions
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision found unreasonable
Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside
Remedy_Sought: Remission to a different RPD panel for re-determination
Decision_Rationale: RPD decision lacked justification, transparency, and intelligibility

Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Counsel failed to submit critical evidence (arrest warrant)
Claimant delayed US asylum claim and returned to Lebanon
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with continuous residency due to return to Lebanon
Procedural_Issue: Incompetence of counsel leading to failure to present key evidence
Evidence_Used: Arrest warrant (not submitted)
Timeline of asylum claims
Travel history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation supporting subjective fear
Credibility_Assessment: Findings of inconsistent behavior regarding fear of return
Doubt on genuineness of refugee claim due to re-entry into Lebanon
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Refugee Protection Division
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a reconstituted Board panel
Decision_Rationale: Counsel incompetence undermined fairness of proceedings
Delay in claiming asylum and return to home country weakened credibility
Findings on subjective fear and re-availment were reasonable but require reassessment in fair process

Application_Facts: Dr. El Ocla was absent from Canada due to professional obligations but maintained strong ties to Canada, including centralized mode of living in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Physical presence not met (1095 days in 4 years), but qualitative residency potentially satisfied
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to consider qualitative residency test under s 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Used: Evidence of professional absences, maintained ties to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not assess evidence relevant to qualitative residency
Decision_Outcome: Original application rejected based solely on physical presence
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by another citizenship judge applying both physical and qualitative tests
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under Citizenship Act; failure to apply qualitative residency test under s 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge erred by not considering the qualitative residency test despite evidence of centralized life in Canada

Application_Facts: The applicants' claim was denied due to credibility issues.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD improperly applied a judicial review standard instead of conducting a proper appeal.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues led to denial of the refugee claim.
Decision_Outcome: RPD's denial of refugee status upheld by RAD initially, then set aside on judicial review.
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remanded to RAD for redetermination.
Relief_Sought: Challenge to the legality of the RAD decision upholding the RPD's denial.
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of the case by the RAD under correct legal standards.
Standard_of_Review: The RAD must conduct an appeal, not a judicial review, applying the correct legal standards.
Decision_Rationale: The RAD failed to conduct a proper appeal and incorrectly applied a judicial review standard.

Crimes.Crime_Name: Knowingly Concealing Material Circumstances in Immigration Process
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Odynsky served as an auxiliary guard at Nazi labor camps during WWII and did not disclose this when applying for Canadian citizenship.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Complied with residency requirements but obtained status through concealment
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose wartime activities that were material to admissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Proceedings initiated by the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction under Canadian citizenship law
Evidence_Used: Testimonies from experts and contemporaries
Historical documents
Security screening records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct documentation of disclosure during initial immigration screening
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found Odynsky's explanation less credible than evidence indicating concealment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deprivation of citizenship under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Admission to Canada was based on failure to disclose material wartime involvement that would have led to rejection

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship revocation based on false representation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Odynsky obtained citizenship through false representation or concealment of material facts
Crimes.Outcome: Citizenship declared obtained by false representation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Court found it more probable than not that Odynsky misrepresented or concealed his wartime role
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 10 and 18 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Involuntary service with German auxiliary forces and failure to disclose during immigration
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Likelihood that disclosure would have resulted in denial of entry
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative hearing under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose material wartime activities on immigration and citizenship applications
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; court relied on available historical and testimonial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: False representation or knowingly concealing material circumstances under s. 10 and s. 18
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and extent of collaboration with Nazi forces
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Declaration that citizenship was obtained by false representation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct document forgery, but omission constituted fraudulent misrepresentation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Exclusion from Convention refugee status under Article 1(E)
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Article 1(E) of the UN Refugee Convention
Crimes.Application_Facts: Vifansi fled U.S. criminal charges and lost re-entry rights; Board assumed 'official status' without proper assessment
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to loss of asylum protection and re-entry rights in the U.S.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Board misapprehended facts regarding applicant's U.S. status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review on grounds of legal error and factual misinterpretation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of U.S. 'official status' affecting Canadian refugee determination
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence that Vifansi lost asylum protection and had no re-entry rights in the U.S.
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to assess actual rights under Article 1(E)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged; decision based on legal misinterpretation
Crimes.Outcome: Remanded for redetermination by a different panel
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Error in law due to incorrect assumption of 'official status'

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion based on prior conduct and status
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of Article 1(E) exclusion due to alleged 'official status' in the U.S.
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board ignored evidence that applicant lost asylum protection and re-entry rights
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish refugee status; Board must properly assess exclusion grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s flight from U.S. criminal charges assessed in context of refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1(E) excludes persons with rights/obligations akin to nationality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misinterpretation of facts and law by the Board
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Loss of asylum protection and lack of re-entry rights in the U.S.
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee determination process under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative decision under judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence on U.S. immigration status
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1(E), UN Refugee Convention

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving flight from prosecution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether fleeing prosecution affects eligibility for refugee status under Article 1(E)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board failed to assess actual rights in the U.S.; relied on incorrect assumptions
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must demonstrate refugee status; exclusion must be properly justified
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Flight to Canada after facing U.S. charges evaluated in refugee context
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1(E) exclusion applies only if individual has rights akin to nationality
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Legal error and misapprehension of facts
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant’s loss of asylum protection and inability to re-enter the U.S.
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian refugee determination system under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not applicable – challenge to administrative decision
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial and documentary evidence on immigration status
Crimes.Outcome: Case remanded to a different panel
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Article 1(E), UN Refugee Convention

Application_Facts: Male applicant appointed as a land surveyor in Haiti; received threats due to political connections; claimed persecution based on this role
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal's failure to properly assess individualized risk; decision found unreasonable on judicial review
Evidence_Used: Threats linked to appointment as land surveyor; political ties; personal targeting evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal overlooked specific evidence of personal targeting
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal initially denied protection, finding only generalized risk
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a person in need of protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a differently constituted tribunal
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal erred by treating the risk as generalized despite evidence of personal targeting related to political circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB); Federal Court on review

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed their visa and applied for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds, citing family reunification and moral support.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants were temporary residents who remained in Canada after their visa expired
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of H&C application within Canadian jurisdiction despite lack of status
Crimes.Evidence_Used: General letter from son emphasizing importance of family unity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of concrete evidence demonstrating unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims based on parental love deemed insufficient to establish significant hardship
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship if required to apply from abroad
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded that applicants failed to demonstrate sufficient hardship or integration to justify H&C relief

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 30(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada without legal status and sought permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds, primarily based on family ties.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants were individuals without valid immigration status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No lawful status; residing in Canada without authorization
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review challenging the assessment of child's best interests and overall reasonableness of decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Consideration of H&C claims by individuals without status residing in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Used: General letter regarding family unity; no documentation of integration or hardship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of significant hardship, deep roots, or exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims not substantiated with objective evidence beyond emotional bonds
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of the immigration officer’s decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Demonstration of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship upon departure
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably determined that applicants did not meet the threshold for H&C relief due to lack of compelling evidence

Violation_Type: Failure to reconsider humanitarian and compassionate application based on new evidence
Application_Facts: Kurukkal failed to initially provide his late wife's death certificate; submitted it after H&C application was refused
Claimant_Status: Applicant for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) relief
Procedural_Issue: Invocation of functus officio to deny reconsideration of H&C application
Evidence_Used: Death certificate of late wife (submitted after initial refusal)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Initial failure to submit death certificate
Decision_Outcome: H&C application initially refused due to missing evidence
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted for reconsideration with new evidence
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of original decision and referral for re-assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Doctrine of functus officio does not bar reconsideration in informal H&C processes
Decision_Rationale: H&C decisions are informal and non-adjudicative, allowing flexibility to consider new evidence even after final decision
Authority_Responsible: Immigration officer responsible for H&C assessment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal of security clearance was based on irrelevant considerations and whether procedural fairness was breached
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 509(c) of the Marine Transportation Security Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's criminal record and continued marijuana use were assessed as relevant to subornment risk
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show unreasonableness or breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's ongoing marijuana use and criminal history affected credibility regarding security risk
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Refusal allowed if reasonable grounds to suspect applicant may be suborned to endanger marine transportation security
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged irrelevance of marijuana use and lack of adequate notice or reasons
Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal record including obstructing a peace officer
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister argued that drug use and criminal history posed a legitimate security concern
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of security clearance denial

Crimes.Crime_Name: Dangerous operation of a motor vehicle
Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Traffic-related offense with potential for harm
Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Individual with criminal history and substance use
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate to high due to repeated offenses and substance involvement
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Elevated risk of subornment in sensitive security environment
Crimes.Risk_Type: Security vulnerability due to potential coercion
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Not applicable – general threat to marine transportation security
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support reasonable suspicion under regulatory standard
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal record, admissions of drug use
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Deemed credible and relevant by reviewing body
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's history undermined trustworthiness for security clearance
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – administrative, not criminal sentencing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 509(c), Marine Transportation Security Regulations

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had recent drug conviction and continued marijuana use
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of notice and reasons in denial process
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal regulatory authority over marine security clearances
Evidence_Used: Criminal record
Continued marijuana use
Associations with criminals
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns about reliability due to illegal drug activity
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Minister’s decision upheld
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and reinstatement of application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable grounds to suspect subornment risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Drug production and use indicate susceptibility to coercion in security-sensitive context

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime under $1000
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative appeal of security clearance denial
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether denial was based on reasonable grounds and met procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 509(c) of the Marine Transportation Security Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Criminal history and drug use evaluated as indicators of subornment risk
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness or unfairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Pattern of criminal behavior and ongoing drug use reduced credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Clearance may be denied if reasonable grounds exist to suspect subornment risk
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that marijuana use was irrelevant and insufficient reasons provided
Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction for possession of stolen property
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minister emphasized legislative purpose of preventing security threats

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant's failure to disclose his marriage prior to becoming a permanent resident violated immigration regulations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant did not disclose marriage before landing in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Wife was not examined before applicant became a permanent resident
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to update application with marital status change
Crimes.Application_Factor: Marriage occurred in May 2004, prior to landing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Wife does not qualify as a family class member
Crimes.Authority: IAD decision under review by Federal Court

Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-disclosure of material change in family status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Paragraph 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant married in May 2004 but did not disclose it before becoming a permanent resident
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with disclosure requirements prior to landing
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of marital status constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No breach of procedural fairness found
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of updated information on marital status
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Wife refused permanent residence; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal of wife’s permanent residence application
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Wife not examined before sponsor became permanent resident; non-accompanying family member not eligible

Crime_Name: Immigration-related humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application denial
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the immigration officer's denial of H&C application
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 25(1)
Evidence_Type: Evidence of integration into Canadian society, personal risk in Guinea, country conditions
Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on hardship and risk
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of sufficient evidence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under subsection 72(1) of the Act
Application_Factor: Integration in Canada, personal risk, country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Denial of H&C exemption upheld

Crime_Name: Importing cocaine contrary to Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Dispute_Type: Deportation appeal based on serious criminality
Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'punished' in s. 64(2) of IRPA; Charter s. 7 compliance
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 64(2), Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; Appeal Division lacked jurisdiction
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish grounds for appeal or Charter breach
Legal_Rule: 'Punished' refers to sentence imposed, not time served; no s. 7 liberty interest in deportation for non-citizens
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of appeal rights under IRPA; alleged Charter s. 7 infringement
Defendant_Response: Challenged deportation due to lack of appeal rights
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of dismissal; restoration of appeal rights

Crime_Name: Acknowledging an instrument in a false name under Criminal Code
Dispute_Type: Deportation appeal based on serious criminality
Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'punished' in s. 64(2) of IRPA; Charter s. 7 compliance
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 64(2), Criminal Code
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; Appeal Division lacked jurisdiction
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish grounds for appeal or Charter breach
Legal_Rule: 'Punished' refers to sentence imposed, not time served; no s. 7 liberty interest in deportation for non-citizens
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of appeal rights under IRPA; alleged Charter s. 7 infringement
Defendant_Response: Challenged dismissal of appeal due to lack of jurisdiction
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of dismissal; restoration of appeal rights

Crime_Name: Discrimination based on race, color, national or ethnic origin, and disability
Dispute_Type: Allegation of racial discrimination and harassment in employment
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission breached its duty of fairness by failing to conduct a thorough investigation
Evidence_Assessment: Investigator failed to explore systemic discrimination claims, made factual errors, overlooked key allegations
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision set aside due to procedural unfairness
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness in investigation
Credibility_Factor: Allegations by Mr. Herbert regarding discriminatory treatment during RCMP employment
Legal_Rule: The Commission must ensure investigations are thorough and fair, considering all relevant evidence before dismissing a complaint
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with attention to procedural fairness
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness, inadequate investigation, failure to address systemic claims
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; complaint remitted for reinvestigation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Herbert’s complaint details, investigator’s report, omissions in investigation
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Commission dismissed complaint under section 44(3)(b) without addressing investigative deficiencies
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, complaint filings, investigation records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of dismissal, new investigation
Outcome: Application allowed; matter remitted for reinvestigation by a different investigator
Legal_Provision: Section 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Refugee status exclusion based on alleged complicity
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity through membership in Mexican army

Application_Facts: The Board excluded the applicant based on his AL membership and linked police abuses to him without direct evidence.
Procedural_Issue: Exclusion issue raised mid-hearing without prior notice, breaching procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Membership in AL, alleged association with police abuses
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct evidence linking applicant to abuses
Decision_Outcome: Excluded under Article 1F(a)
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remanded for rehearing
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to consider commission of crimes against humanity
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence and procedural unfairness in applying Article 1F(a) exclusion

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim exclusion under international law
Legal_Issue: Whether Article 1F(a) exclusion was properly applied without sufficient evidence or procedural fairness
Evidence_Assessment: No direct link between applicant’s role and human rights abuses; role as youth leader not equated to control over police
Decision_Outcome: Excluded from refugee protection under Article 1F(a)
Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to show serious reasons for considering commission of crimes
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claims of persecution in Bangladesh
Legal_Rule: Complicity requires personal and knowing participation in crimes against humanity
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in human rights abuses by political party
Outcome_on_Merits: Board’s decision found flawed due to lack of evidence and fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's leadership role in political party, reports of police abuses
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred for rehearing

Legal_Provision_Involved: Subsection 44(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether applicants were denied procedural fairness by being denied cross-examination of the enforcement officer
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Applicants had access to the admissibility report
Decision_Outcome: Applications dismissed
Authority_Responsible: Immigration enforcement authority, Federal Court for review
Criminal_Activity: Alleged organized criminality related to immigration
Risk_Nexus: Connection between applicant and organized criminal activity
Evidence_Source: Admissibility report prepared by Officer Clare
Decision_Maker: Enforcement officer (Officer Clare), reviewed by Federal Court
Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found; applications dismissed
Basis_for_Decision: Low level of procedural fairness required under subsection 44(1); written submissions sufficient
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to procedural fairness

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Legal_Provision_Involved: Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act s. 6
Grounds_for_Claim: Personal and knowing participation in crimes against humanity through role in Republican Guard and handing over prisoners for 'strong interrogations'
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Decision_Outcome: Mr. Vivar found complicit; declared inadmissible to Canada
Institutional_Action: Immigration Division decision upheld by Federal Court
Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court of Canada
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 35(1), s. 72(1); Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act s. 6

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Legal_Provision_Involved: Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act s. 6
Grounds_for_Claim: Complicity in crimes against humanity due to service in Peruvian Republican Guard, awareness of torture, and transfer of prisoners for abuse
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act
Decision_Outcome: Mr. Vivar's inadmissibility confirmed based on complicity
Institutional_Action: Immigration Division decision reviewed and upheld
Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court of Canada
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 35(1), s. 72(1); Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act s. 6

Dispute_Type: Refusal of permanent residence application based on financial inadmissibility
Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer properly weighed humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) factors against inadmissibility under Section 39 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Law: Section 25 and Section 39 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review following refusal of H&C application
Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to assess H&C factors in relation to inadmissibility; focused on disproportionate hardship without addressing inadmissibility
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; original decision quashed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate that H&C factors outweigh inadmissibility, but officer must properly assess both sides
Credibility_Factor: Claims of domestic abuse and humanitarian grounds were raised but not adequately assessed
Legal_Rule: Section 25 requires weighing H&C factors against inadmissibility; binding effect of Justice Hughes' Order
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, compliance with prior court orders
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to follow Justice Hughes' Order, improper assessment of H&C versus inadmissibility
Outcome_on_Merits: Success on judicial review due to procedural error and failure to apply correct legal framework
Key_Evidence_Considered: Domestic abuse claims, financial inadmissibility, humanitarian and compassionate factors
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, court precedents, prior judicial orders
Defendant_Response: PRRA officer did not address inadmissibility in light of H&C factors as required
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal affidavits, legal submissions
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision and remittal for redetermination
Outcome: Decision remitted to a different officer for reassessment in accordance with Justice Hughes' Order

Legal_Issue: Whether 'Glen Breton' is deceptively misdescriptive under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: No Canadian whisky with 'Glen' in name before 2000; 'Glen' associated with Scottish whisky; consumer confusion evidence introduced on appeal
Decision_Outcome: Trademark application for 'Glen Breton' refused
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate registrability; opponent showed likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: New evidence of consumer confusion admitted on appeal
Legal_Rule: Marks that are deceptively misdescriptive or have recognized geographic association are not registrable
Grounds_for_Claim: 'Glen Breton' falsely suggests Scotch origin due to use of 'Glen'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commercial usage of 'Glen' in whisky branding; absence of prior Canadian use; consumer perception data
Defendant_Response: Glenora Distillers defended trademark application as distinctive and not misleading
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, commercial usage records, consumer survey data (implied)
Remedy_Requested: Refusal of trademark registration by Scotch Whisky Association
